review: The pacing of the story struggled to maintain my engagement. I found myself pausing multiple times in the first third of the book, needing to push through to continue.

I noticed a potential plot hole concerning the planet's rotation. If it doesn't rotate on its own axis while orbiting a star, there would still be a day/night cycle lasting an entire year. For one side to constantly face the sun, the planet would need to be tidally locked, similar to the relationship between the moon and Earth. Unless there was an explanation about Tampere's slow axial rotation that I missed, this appears to be an oversight.

The author is known for delivering surprising revelations and twists, and while there were some in the final third of the book, they felt too little, too late. By that point, I had already anticipated many of the twists, which made the experience somewhat repetitive compared to her previous work, *Magic Bitter, Magic Sweet*.
I was captivated by the premise of *Still the Sun*. It was intriguing and full of potential.
